newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Asian crude steady, relief Oman trades at premium.
newsitem.headline: Asian crude steady, relief Oman trades at premium.

text.p: Asia crude prices were steady to firmer on Tuesday as sellers indicated some relief that first Oman April deals were at a premium.
Traders said two cargos of April Oman were traded at MPM +3 cents and +4 cents -- levels which most traders deemed as reasonable given expectations of a much weaker market.
The traded levels were lower than March deals, although one late March deal was heard between MPM +1/5 cents.
"Anything that shows trading has been done at a reasonable level is not a bad start," one trader said, reflecting the view that Oman could dip in coming days to a discount to MPM.
Oman's differential with quoted Dubai went out to $1.14 per barrel for April trading from $1.04 when most players had expected the differential to come in to reflect the weaker seasonal trend.
Paper markets were also steady with Brent/Dubai and Dubai intermonths spreads little change from Monday.
A second-quarter Dubai traded between European majors at $17.85 per barrel.
March Tapis swaps were also holding day-earlier levels, quoted at $22.05/$22.30 per barrel. A second quarter/four quarter spread was traded at 91 cents.
Regional markets were quiet as Indonesia players waited for the final March allocation figures from Pertamina.
Traders said they expected the Minas allocation to be at least 100,000 barrels per day (bpd), if not higher at 120,000/130,000 bpd due to the Dumai refinery turnaround.
Other allocations, such as for Duri are also expected to rise owing to the Dumai shut down.
This was already depressing prices, with Minas talked in a range of ICP 30 to 60 cents.
